stem: A 58-year-old client received a transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells 7 days ago. The client returns to the clinic reporting fatigue and yellowing of the eyes. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: This is regarding a possible late transfusion complication. The patient is a 58-year-old who received a blood transfusion 7 days ago and is now presenting with fatigue and jaundice.
Background: The patient has a history of anemia and has received multiple transfusions in the past. The most recent transfusion was during knee surgery a week ago.
Assessment: At 09:00, the client exhibited mild scleral icterus and reported dark-colored urine. Laboratory results indicate a decrease in hematocrit since discharge, and the DAT (Coombs) test is now positive.
Recommendation: I recommend ordering a Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT) and a Bilirubin screen to assess for a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction. Consider IV fluids to support renal perfusion.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: No medications administered in relation to the current presentation.

actionOptions.text: Notify the Blood Bank to screen for newly developed antibodies.
Administer IV fluids to maintain renal perfusion as prescribed.
Perform a STAT needle decompression of the chest.
Apply cooling blankets and withhold all lab work.

parameterOptions.text: Serum Indirect Bilirubin and Haptoglobin levels
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing a Delayed Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (DHTR) (c2), which typically occurs 3–14 days after transfusion due to an amnestic (memory) response to a previously encountered minor blood group antigen. This leads to the destruction of transfused red blood cells. Signs include a falling Hgb, rising indirect bilirubin (jaundice), dark urine, and a positive Coombs test (DAT). The nurse must notify the Blood Bank (a1) so future units can be cross-matched for the new antibody. Supporting the kidneys with IV fluids (a2) helps clear the hemoglobin breakdown products, preventing acute tubular necrosis. Tracking Hgb (p1) monitors the ongoing hemolysis, and Bilirubin/Haptoglobin (p2) assesses the severity of red cell breakdown.
clinicalPearls: Acute Hemolytic Transfusion Reactions are usually due to ABO incompatibility, while Delayed Hemolytic Transfusion Reactions are due to minor blood group antigen incompatibility (Rh, Kidd, Kell).
Jaundice and dark urine occur because the body is breaking down red cells faster than the liver can process the bilirubin.
DHTR is often missed because the symptoms appear after the patient has been discharged from the hospital.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking this is a new bleed because the Hgb dropped.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look at the Bilirubin and Urine! If the Hgb drops AND the Bilirubin rises/Urine is dark, it's hemolysis, not just an active bleed. A positive DAT confirms the presence of antibodies attacking the transfused red cells.

mnemonic.title: Delayed = Days
mnemonic.expansion: D-Days later. E-Eyes yellow (Jaundice). L-Lower Hgb. A-Antibody developed. Y-You must notify the blood bank!
